issue.title: Show most recent build time for a mod

labels.name: Contributions Welcome/Easy
labels.description: Simpler Issues suitable for first time contributors

labels.name: Requestor-Modders
labels.description: Issues or PRs adding or fixing TML modder API

issue.body:
### Do you intend to personally contribute/program this feature?

No

### I would like to see this change made to improve my experience with

Mod capability as a Modder

### Description

Display the time that the current build of a mod finished in the 'Develop Mods' menu. 

Ideally time would be displayed in either relative time if possible (like discord timestamps - `Last build N minutes ago`) or in the standard time format for the country of the user (although i can see potential problems with this, depending on whether the time gets automatically converted to the local format or not)

I envision this information being displayed either next to the mod's name, or as a tooltip of sorts when hovering over the mod. 

### What does this proposal attempt to solve or improve?

This feature would help the more easily distracted modders like myself, who have a habit of looking away while the mod is being built, and forgetting whether you just build the mod or not upon getting back on task. 

Admittedly, this is a very low urgency feature, and probably not really necessary, but i think it would be a nice thing to have.

Additionally, I may be able to help/program this feature myself, but since i wouldn't have any idea where to start looking i have selected no in the above option, especially because it would be much faster if someone who knows what they are doing would implement this instead.  

### Which (other) solutions should be considered?

_No response_

commits.message:
Show most recent build time for a mod (#3898)

* add last build time

* add const  localization key

* improved localization entries

* Simplify, reduce code and localization duplication

* Update LocalMod.cs

* Update TimeHelper.cs

---------

Co-authored-by: JavidPack <javidpack@gmail.com>

pull_request.title: Show most recent build time for a mod
pull_request.body:
### What is the new feature?
Adds the time that the current build of a mod finished in 'Mod Sources'. Closes #3653
Example:
- `Last build N seconds/minutes/hours/days/months/years ago`, 
- `Last build just now`.  

### Why should this be part of tModLoader?
Gives the modder a bit more information about the mod source. Sometimes you can forget if you've built it recently.

### Are there alternative designs?
No

### Sample usage for the new feature
https://streamable.com/alookp

repo.name: tModLoader
repo.description: A mod to make and play Terraria mods. Supports Terraria 1.4 (and earlier) installations

review.body:
Hmm. I agree with JavidPack's assessment that adding an additional check of last built version likely won't be of huge benefit. 
This isn't in your face and aggravating (unlike some other games), so I think this is reasonable implementation.

On the code side, some minor comments error handling surrounding the Steam web query

pull_request.title: Show latest news on main menu
pull_request.body:
We've found it difficult to keep modders and mod users updated with information. This PR suggests implementing a small notification in the main menu to prompt interested users and modders to click to read the latest tModLoader news.

Posting breaking changes to just Discord doesn't reach our full audience, some mod teams subscribe to our announcement channel within their own Discord servers, but not all do that. Users might notice news on Steam, but might not.

This adds one more way for modders and users to be exposed to the latest tModLoader news. 

The video shows the behavior in action. On reaching the main menu, the steam news api is checked. The news title will be displayed. If the news is newer than previously seen news, it'll display as disco colors to bring attention to it. Once clicked or next game session, the notification will be a less attention grabbing white color:

https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/assets/4522492/a348eddb-dc1a-4f73-a7c1-566631901b74

Unfortunately, we can't easily access localized versions of these news entries using the web api (the current code only cares about the title), maybe that is something we could look into.

repo.name: tModLoader

comment.body:
Consider error handling in the event computer / steam host is offline to minimize logged text.

Consider error handling for various steam responses: https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/webapi_overview/responses#status_codes

comment.body:
> > on steam
> 
> yeah but i found how to fix that : -do a backup of your mods -unistall terraria (and tmod) -re install your game via steam -replace tmod in your file -and when you start tmodloader don't press enter when you see the red text just close the console that's all

Thank you, man! It helps! 👍

forkee.name: tModLoader
forkee.description: A mod to make and play Terraria mods. Supports Terraria 1.4 (and earlier) installations

pull_request.title: Docker and Management Script Bugfixes
pull_request.body:
### What is the bug?
Currently the Docker container doesn't capture Ctrl+C while TML does, meaning that a user could lose data between the last autosave if they try to close the server with SIGINT

### How did you fix the bug?
Switched away from spawning a new process with `/bin/bash` in favor of the in-process replacement `./scriptname.sh`. This release also fixes the management script pulling pre-releases from Github

### Are there alternatives to your fix?
Not really, besides maybe switching to `exec` in the ENTRYPOINT

issue.body:
We've found it difficult to keep modders and mod users updated with information. This PR suggests implementing a small notification in the main menu to prompt interested users and modders to click to read the latest tModLoader news.

Posting breaking changes to just Discord doesn't reach our full audience, some mod teams subscribe to our announcement channel within their own Discord servers, but not all do that. Users might notice news on Steam, but might not.

This adds one more way for modders and users to be exposed to the latest tModLoader news.

If the news is newer than previously seen news, it'll display as disco colors to bring attention to it. Once clicked or next game session, the notification will be a less attention grabbing white color:

https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/assets/4522492/a348eddb-dc1a-4f73-a7c1-566631901b74

Unfortunately, we can't easily access localized versions of these news entries using the web api (the current code only cares about the title), maybe that is something we could look into.

comment.body: I'm not sure an additional check is needed. Even if a user is automatically updated, they would still be interested in what actually updated. They might have noticed that a mod suddenly is broken, the flashing color would suggest to them somewhere to look for clues. We usually post the announcement when the build goes live, so there never is really any upcoming changes unless a user is launching an old manually installed release.

issue.title: Cannot rebinding to "oem" keys
issue.body:
### Version

Latest public-1.4-alpha

### OS

Windows

### Platform

Steam

### Description

I am unable to rebind keybindings to most "oem" keys ('^', '$', 'ù').
Manually editing "input profiles.json" (pasting the value of the key from the vanilla file) makes the correct key display but the input is not registered.

### Log File

[Main Thread/WARN] [FNA]: KEY/SCANCODE MISSING FROM SDL2->XNA DICTIONARY: SDLK_DOLLAR SDL_SCANCODE_RIGHTBRACKET
[client.log](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/files/7541308/client.log)



### Steps to reproduce

1. Try to rebind to '^', '$' or '!' .
2. Edit 'input profiles.json': change the value of a key to "OemCloseBrackets"(value from the vanilla "input profiles.json" file).

### Expected Behavior

The key should be remapped to the '^' and work in game (in my case open the inventory).

### Actual Behavior

When rebinding: Nothing happens and the game is waiting for a key press .
Editing "input profiles.json": The correct key display in game but pressing the key does nothing.


### Reproduction frequency

Always.

### Additional Information

Works perfectly fine in vanilla 1.4 and tml 1.3.

comment.body:
I use a French AZERTY keyboard and this fix worked for every key except the '<' key on my keyboard, but there's no error message.
I also noticed it uses a different layout from the vanilla game (in vanilla, '<' rebinds to OEMBackslash), maybe this is why it doesn't work for this key.

Here is my layout:
![schema_azerty_simple_transparent_1800x627-1863691324](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/assets/88098360/d0d8b04c-4d78-45db-88bf-6247933cfbd8)

forkee.name: tModLoader

pull_request.title: #3887 Allow Player.Save/LoadPlayer from stream
pull_request.body:
[What is the new feature?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#what-is-the-new-feature)

Refine save/load functions.

[Why should this be part of tModLoader?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#why-should-this-be-part-of-tmodloader)

The current save and load parameters only allow path, which means that data generation and writing are inseparable.And because the player data is divided into two parts, PLR and TPLR, it is difficult for Hook to obtain them simultaneously.

This change does not break the original interface and allows developers to obtain players directly from binary data without using path, making “memory player” possible.

[Are there alternative designs?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#are-there-alternative-designs)

No, 

[Sample usage for the new feature](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#sample-usage-for-the-new-feature)

If you have a player's data, it can be used without writing files or hooks.

```
byte[] plr_data = ... // from plr file or packet
TagCompound tplr_data = ... // from tplr file or packet
var streamPlayer = Player.LoadPlayerFromStream(new PlayerFileData, plr_data, tplr_data);
```

```
byte[] plr_data = Player.GeneratePlayerData(playerFile);
TagCompound tplr_data = PlayerIO.SaveData();

Player.UpdateLocalPlayerFile, this function can easily redirect save to what you want.
```

pull_request.title: #3887 Allow Player.Save/LoadPlayer from stream
pull_request.body:
[What is the new feature?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#what-is-the-new-feature)

Refine save/load functions.

[Why should this be part of tModLoader?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#why-should-this-be-part-of-tmodloader)

The current save and load parameters only allow path, which means that data generation and writing are inseparable.And because the player data is divided into two parts, PLR and TPLR, it is difficult for Hook to obtain them simultaneously.

This change does not break the original interface and allows developers to obtain players directly from binary data without using path, making “memory player” possible.

[Are there alternative designs?](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#are-there-alternative-designs)

No, 

[Sample usage for the new feature](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/1.4.4/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/new_feature.md#sample-usage-for-the-new-feature)

If you have a player's data, it can be used without writing files or hooks.

```
byte[] plr_data = ... // from plr file or packet
TagCompound tplr_data = ... // from tplr file or packet
var streamPlayer = Player.LoadPlayerFromStream(new PlayerFileData, plr_data, tplr_data);
```

```
byte[] plr_data = Player.InternalSavePlayerFile_Part1(playerFile);
TagCompound tplr_data = PlayerIO.SaveData();

On.InternalSavePlayerFile_Part2, this function can easily redirect save.
```

comment.body: I've received confirmation that this is a Terraria bug, and have communicated this bug with the Terraria team. I'll be closing this since it's up to them now. The hope is that this will be fixed in an upcoming release.

issue.title: Cannot rebinding to "oem" keys
issue.body:
### Version

Latest public-1.4-alpha

### OS

Windows

### Platform

Steam

### Description

I am unable to rebind keybindings to most "oem" keys ('^', '$', 'ù').
Manually editing "input profiles.json" (pasting the value of the key from the vanilla file) makes the correct key display but the input is not registered.

### Log File

[Main Thread/WARN] [FNA]: KEY/SCANCODE MISSING FROM SDL2->XNA DICTIONARY: SDLK_DOLLAR SDL_SCANCODE_RIGHTBRACKET
[client.log](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/files/7541308/client.log)



### Steps to reproduce

1. Try to rebind to '^', '$' or '!' .
2. Edit 'input profiles.json': change the value of a key to "OemCloseBrackets"(value from the vanilla "input profiles.json" file).

### Expected Behavior

The key should be remapped to the '^' and work in game (in my case open the inventory).

### Actual Behavior

When rebinding: Nothing happens and the game is waiting for a key press .
Editing "input profiles.json": The correct key display in game but pressing the key does nothing.


### Reproduction frequency

Always.

### Additional Information

Works perfectly fine in vanilla 1.4 and tml 1.3.

comment.body:
I took a look at this today, I might have a solution.

[ScriptCaller.zip](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/files/13142465/ScriptCaller.zip)

Take the file inside this zip and replace the existing file in the LaunchUtils folder within your install directory. Then launch the game. I tested it locally by changing the keyboard language, I'm not sure if a physical keyboard of a different language would behave differently. My testing suggests that it works the same as Terraria now, but it's hard to test since my keys don't match up. The keys are now detected at least, but they still will show OEM_Something that might not match up with what you see printed on your keyboard.

If anyone comes across this issue and can confirm the fix, we can look into making it the default.

issue.title: Can't use # key as keybind

labels.name: Requestor-Player
labels.description: Issues or PRs adding player features or fixing TML gameplay bugs

issue.body:
### Version

Latest 1.4-stable

### OS

Windows

### Platform

Steam

### This bug affects

Gameplay as a Player

### Description

Can't use # on French Canada keyboard. It is the key on the left side of 1 aka OemTilde when I use English keyboard on windows. In Terraria 1.4 in my input profiles.json, it is known as OemQuotes, but for some reasons it won't let me use it at all in the controls menu, but I can write it in the chat. 

Works in vanilla Terraria 1.4 and was working on tmod 1.3

In the log bellow I'll attach the message it adds everytime I try to bind it. 

### Log File

[20:04:13.449] [Main Thread/WARN] [FNA]: KEY/SCANCODE MISSING FROM SDL2->XNA DICTIONARY: SDLK_HASH SDL_SCANCODE_GRAVE

### Steps to reproduce

1. Set French Canadian QWERTY keyboard in windows
2. open controls in terraria and try to use the key left to the "1" above "tab"

### Expected Behavior

Should be allowing me to bind it and seems to be knowns as OemQuotes in vanilla Terraria within the input profile json file.

### Actual Behavior

nothing happens and shows an error in the log file (client.log btw)

### Reproduction frequency

always.

### Additional Information

N/A

comment.body:
I took a look at this today, I might have a solution.

[ScriptCaller.zip](https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/files/13142465/ScriptCaller.zip)

Take the file inside this zip and replace the existing file in the LaunchUtils folder within your install directory. Then launch the game. I tested it locally by changing the keyboard language, I'm not sure if a physical keyboard of a different language would behave differently. My testing suggests that it works the same as Terraria now, but it's hard to test since my keys don't match up. The keys are now detected at least, but they still will show OEM_Something that might not match up with what you see printed on your keyboard.

If anyone comes across this issue and can confirm the fix, we can look into making it the default.

pull_request.title: Show most recent build time for a mod
pull_request.body:
### What is the new feature?
Adds the time that the current build of a mod finished in 'Mod Sources'. For example `Last build N seconds/minutes/hours/years ago`, `Last build just now`. Closes #3653 

### Why should this be part of tModLoader?
Gives the modder a bit more information about the mod source. Sometimes you can forget if you've built it recently.

### Are there alternative designs?
No

### Sample usage for the new feature
https://streamable.com/8m96ci

### Notes
I added some entries to tModLoader.json files but wasn't sure the best way to handle localization for this, since the order of words could be in different positions depending on the language.
